title: The Block 2019 episode 42 recap: Scott Cam blows his stack at Jesse
text:
Scott Cam has already blown his stack a couple of times this season — at Mark and Mitch’s insinuations he is a homophobe, and at the teams constantly complaining about not having enough money.

This episode makes it a third time the affable chippie pulls on his poopy pants and lets rip.

Jesse, who had made a pretty good fist of redeeming his smart-arse rep over the past few weeks, reverts to form in blaming the world for he and his carpenter’s stuff up.

RELATED:

Episode 41 recap: Room brings Shaynna Blaze to tears

The five best kids’ bedrooms of season 13

The teams are doing two verandas this episode, and Jesse and his chippie are flying, getting the ceiling boards up on their level two balcony hours ahead of any other team.

They’re making similarly quick work of the level three outside area when something called a hip joint brings them undone.

Only the two end homes (Jess and Mel’s and Mark and Mitch’s) need to work around this 45 degree join. Unfortunately, they’re not precisely 45 degrees. That’s because the entire 170 year old building isn’t completely square. The tradies who built it didn’t have the advantages of modern tools, so Keith and Dan’s team have had to make their own adjustments as they put in the various additions. If they didn’t adjust, the entire new veranda would be hanging out to the side of the building.

Unfortunately for Jesse, he and his carpenter didn’t heed Dan’s warning to double check the joint and now Jesse wants compensation for his carpenter’s four wasted hours — $600 to be precise.

Jesse says it’s a mistake not of his making. And it is, but it’s a mistake made by a long dead chippie, and Scott Cam is in no mood to foot the bill for his historical colleague.

Jesse complains the job hasn’t been done right, and he is the victim, Cam tells Jesse he shouldn’t have gone ahead and cut all his boards before double checking, and the impasse ends with Cam saying “Stop, stop, stop. I said stop! You let me speak right! You’re not even listening. This is the end of the story. As for I’m going to pay your bill, I’m paying nothing, mate. You get it done and you get it done right.”

Meanwhile, Mark and Mitch’s builder has immediately seen the need to improvise around the slightly off hip joint and adjusted his cuts accordingly. As if Mark and Mitch needed any more reasons to be smug.

That pair really reveal their nasty streak in this episode.

They’re bitter that their former mates Tess and Luke said no to them having a spa on their outside deck, and after having spent the entire season denying that their party floor will have any impact on their neighbours’ master bedroom — which shares a wall with the aforementioned private nightclub — they’re now taking great delight in crowing about the fact it will make life unbearable for whoever buys Tess and Luke’s house.

They’re putting a huge dining table and in-built speaker system in their veranda, just outside Tess and Luke’s masterbedroom.

“For a nice 16 person dinner party, lots of conversation, laughing their heads off, after a few red wines the music goes up. There’s a master next door. Oh well! And they thought that a spa motor was going to be a problem,” Mitch says, in a mean-spirited diatribe that really does him no credit, particularly given Tess and Luke really are this season’s Bambi and Thumper.

Mitch had earlier tipped a bucket on Tess and Luke’s winning studio room from last week.

“It doesn’t work,” Mitch says. “It’s an absolute joke.”

The other teams disagree, complimenting the pair for putting a full kitchen in and making good opportunity of the separate entrance.

Mind you when Tess and Luke inspect Mark and Mitch’s room — which would have tied for first place if Tess and Luke hadn’t used their bonus point — she’s equally uncomplimentary, parking herself on their toilet saying “Thank god because I need a poo, and what better place to do a poo than somewhere you’ve been shat all over.”

She follows it up by miming wiping her bum with one of Mitch and Mark’s towels.

She might be Bambi, but nobody would ever accuse of her being classy.
